# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 170, 250]]<|/det|>

CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 214, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 309, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 870, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 215, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 628, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\theta\) is an acute angle in degrees such that \(\sin \theta = \frac{2}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 410, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\sin (\theta + 60^{\circ})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 442, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 3\tan \frac{1}{2}x\cos 2x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 108, 593, 127]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point for which \(x = \frac{1}{3}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 918, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 722, 92]]<|/det|>
Sketch, on the same diagram, the graphs of \(y = |3x - 5|\) and \(y = 2x + 7\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 148, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 448, 463]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(|3x - 5| = 2x + 7.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 144, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 688, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
Hence solve the equation \(\left|3^{y + 1} - 5\right| = 2\times 3^{y} + 7\), giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 704, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 393, 92]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 100, 608, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{p}(x) = 6x^{3} + ax^{2} + bx - 20,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 917, 163]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) and that the remainder is \(-11\) when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x + 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 174, 146, 192]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 174, 373, 192]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 174, 918, 192]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 776, 92]]<|/det|>
Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), and determine the exact roots of the equation \(\mathrm{p}(3x) = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 643, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\cos \mathrm{e} \theta (3 \sin 2 \theta + 4 \sin^{3} \theta) \equiv 4 + 6 \cos \theta - 4 \cos^{2} \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 650, 311, 668]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 664, 636, 685]]<|/det|>
\[\cos \mathrm{e} \theta (3 \sin 2 \theta + 4 \sin^{3} \theta) + 3 = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 280, 707]]<|/det|>
for \(-\pi < \theta < 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 749, 92]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation \(\mathrm{e}^{2x} - 18x + \mathrm{y}^{3} + \mathrm{y} = 11\) has a stationary point at \((p, q)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 363, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 405, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that \(q = \sqrt[3]{2 + 18\ln 3 - q}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 384, 181, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 383, 670, 401]]<|/det|>
Show by calculation that the value of \(q\) lies between 2.5 and 3.0.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 383, 918, 401]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 591, 148, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 590, 918, 624]]<|/det|>
Use an iterative formula, based on the equation in (b), to find the value of \(q\) correct to 4 significant figures. Give the result of each iteration to 6 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 604, 918, 623]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 567, 92]]<|/det|>
# Additional Page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
If you use the following lined page to complete the answer(s) to any question(s), the question number(s) must be clearly shown.
